item.title: Govt lab confirms HMPV infection in 8-yr-old, cases rise to three in Gujarat - The Indian Express
item.description:
Govt lab confirms HMPV infection in 8-yr-old, cases rise to three in Gujarat

Date: January 11, 2025

Source: Indian Express

An eight-year-old boy from Gujarat’s Sabarkantha district has contracted human metapneumovirus infection, bringing the total number of cases in the state to three. Health authorities had sent his blood samples to a government lab for confirmation after initial testing.

  • The boy is a farm laborer's child from Prantij taluka.
  • He is hospitalized in Himmatnagar and his condition is stable.
  • The first case in Gujarat was reported on January 6 in a two-month-old boy.
  • An 80-year-old man also tested positive for HMPV in Ahmedabad.
  • HMPV spreads through respiratory droplets and contact with infected individuals.
“The government lab on Friday confirmed that the boy is infected with HMPV. He is currently under treatment and his condition is stable,” said Sabarkantha District Collector Ratankanvar Gadhavicharan.

The rising cases of HMPV in Gujarat highlight the importance of awareness and early detection of respiratory pathogens.

item.title: Best Immune-Boosting Foods to Eat During Winter to Help You Stay Healthy - Healthline
item.description:
Best Immune-Boosting Foods to Eat During Winter to Help You Stay Healthy

Date: October 2023 | Source: Healthline

As winter approaches, maintaining a robust immune system is crucial due to the increase in respiratory illnesses. This article highlights various nutrient-rich foods that can help bolster immunity during the winter months.

  • Certain whole foods are vital for health in winter.
  • Foods like root vegetables, citrus, nuts, and berries are rich in vitamins and antioxidants.
  • A strong immune system is essential to combat respiratory illnesses prevalent in colder climates.
William Schaffner, MD: “We spend more time indoors, crowded together during the winter… These close personal contacts provide ample opportunities for these respiratory viruses to spread.”

Maintaining a balanced diet year-round is important, but specific attention to winter nutrition can enhance immunity. Experts recommend increasing consumption of vitamin D, A, and C to prevent infections.

item.title: Can HMPV affect your kidneys? Signs and symptoms to watch out for - The Times of India
item.description:
Can HMPV affect your kidneys? Signs and symptoms to watch out for

Publication Date: October 2023 Source: [Source Name]

HMPV (Human Metapneumovirus) can lead to serious kidney issues; understanding symptoms is crucial.

  • HMPV is a respiratory virus that may also impact kidney function.
  • Common symptoms include cough, fever, and shortness of breath.
  • Patients should monitor for unusual urination or swelling.
  • Healthcare providers recommend seeking advice if symptoms escalate.
“Understanding the signs of HMPV can prevent severe health complications.”

The awareness of HMPV’s effects on kidneys highlights the need for vigilance among affected individuals.

item.title: This brain-boosting Indian herb is becoming popular globally; know all about it - The Times of India
item.description:
This brain-boosting Indian herb is becoming popular globally; know all about it

Publication Date: Not specified Source: Not specified

In recent times, an Indian herb known for its cognitive-enhancing properties is gaining worldwide attention. This article explores its benefits, historical significance, and the reasons for its rising popularity.

  • The herb is traditionally used in Ayurvedic medicine.
  • It is praised for its potential to improve memory and mental clarity.
  • Many people globally are starting to incorporate it into their diets.
"This herb could change the way we think about boosting brain health.”

As this brain-boosting herb continues to capture interest, it may play a vital role in modern wellness trends.

item.title: Cambodian man dies from bird flu - Medical Xpress
item.description:
Cambodian Man Dies from H5N1 Bird Flu After Consuming Sick Chickens

Date: January 10, 2025 Source: Medical Xpress

A 28-year-old man from Kampong Cham province, Cambodia, has died from bird flu after consuming sick chickens. He tested positive for the H5N1 virus.

  • The patient exhibited critical symptoms including fever, coughing, and difficulty breathing.
  • In 2023, at least three people in Cambodia have died from bird flu, including a two-year-old girl.
  • The World Health Organization has warned about inadequate influenza surveillance in relation to H5N1.
  • The victim had raised poultry and reportedly cooked sick chickens for food.
  • Authorities are investigating the outbreak and urging vigilance among the public.
"Bird flu H5N1 remains a threat to the health of our people." - Cambodian Health Ministry

The ongoing global outbreak of H5N1 has led to severe outbreaks in Europe and the Americas, resulting in the culling of millions of domestic poultry and the deaths of tens of thousands of wild birds.

item.title: Woman from Myanmar undergoes liver transplant at hospital in Chennai - The Hindu
item.description:
Woman from Myanmar undergoes liver transplant at hospital in Chennai

Published: January 10, 2025 08:51 pm IST

A 66-year-old woman from Myanmar underwent a liver transplant surgery at a private hospital in Chennai after being diagnosed with advanced liver disease.

  • The woman suffered from ascites, pedal oedema, and jaundice due to hepatitis C virus-induced hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • The surgery was led by Magnus Jayaraj and Karthik Raj M. at GEM Hospitals.
  • A living donor liver transplant was performed with her niece donating a part of her liver.
  • The patient is now recovering and preparing to return to Myanmar.

item.title: Live Updates | HMPV Cases in India Live: Total Case Count Increases To 13, 2 New HMPV Virus Reported - Zee News
item.description:
Live Updates | HMPV Cases in India Live: Total Case Count Increases To 13 2 New HMPV Virus Reported

Last Updated: Jan 10, 2025, 08:49 PM IST | Source: Zee News

The Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) is causing concern in India as the total case count increases to 13. Authorities are monitoring the situation and providing guidelines.

  • 11 cases reported across various cities: 2 in Bengaluru, 1 in Gujarat, 2 in Chennai, 3 in Kolkata, 2 in Nagpur, and 1 in Mumbai.
  • The virus, first identified in 2001, has been around globally for many years.
  • HMPV RT-PCR tests are priced between Rs 3,000 to Rs 8,000; comprehensive tests can reach Rs 20,000.
  • There are concerns about the spread of HMPV during the Mahakumbh festival attended by millions.
The Union Health Minister noted that the government is prepared to address any potential rise in respiratory illnesses.

Authorities encourage the public to stay informed and vigilant as they navigate this health concern.

item.title: 45-minute sauna lands woman in hospital due to heat stroke - The Times of India
item.description:
Woman Hospitalized After 45-Minute Sauna Session Leads to Heat Stroke

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Not specified

A woman was hospitalized after suffering from heat stroke following a lengthy sauna session lasting 45 minutes. This incident raises awareness about the risks associated with prolonged exposure to high temperatures.

  • A woman experienced heat stroke after a 45-minute sauna visit.
  • The event underscores the health risks of extended sauna use.
  • Proper hydration and moderation are emphasized for sauna users.
“Users should always listen to their bodies and seek medical attention if they feel unwell.”

This incident serves as a reminder to prioritize safety during sauna use and maintain awareness of personal health limits.

item.title: Third HMPV case reported from Ahmedabad, state tally reaches four - Gujarat Samachar
item.description:
Third HMPV Case Reported in Ahmedabad, Tally Reaches Four in Gujarat

Publication Date: Friday | Source: Gujarat Samachar

A new HMPV case has been reported from Ahmedabad, bringing the state's total to four cases. This incident marks the third reported case from Ahmedabad.

  • The latest patient is a nine-month-old infant transferred from Viha Children’s Hospital to Childhood Hospital.
  • The previous case involved an 80-year-old man who tested positive and was admitted to Sterling Hospital.
  • Three cases of HMPV have been confirmed in Ahmedabad and one in Prantij.
  • HMPV is a respiratory virus that tends to peak in winter, particularly affecting young children and the elderly.
  • Advisory issued by the state urges citizens to follow health guidelines to combat respiratory infections.
“Metapneumovirus (HMPV) is similar to other respiratory viruses, and it's crucial to maintain hygiene and avoid crowded places to prevent infection.”

Citizens are advised to cover their mouths when sneezing, wash hands regularly, and seek medical attention if they exhibit respiratory symptoms.

item.title: Even 1 drink a day elevates your cancer risk – an expert on how alcohol affects the body breaks down a new government report - The Conversation
item.description:
Even 1 drink a day elevates your cancer risk – an expert on how alcohol affects the body breaks down a new government report

Date: January 3, 2025 Source: U.S. Surgeon General

A new Surgeon General Advisory warns that consuming as little as 1-2 alcoholic drinks per day can significantly elevate cancer risks.

  • The report highlights that alcohol leads to approximately 100,000 cancer cases and 20,000 cancer deaths annually.
  • Breast cancer risk particularly rises with alcohol consumption, causing concern amid increasing use among women.
  • Only a quarter of cancer cases linked to alcohol occur among heavy drinkers; many moderate drinkers are also affected.
  • The report advocates for updated warning labels on alcoholic beverages similar to tobacco products.
“Alcohol is the third-most preventable cause of cancer in the U.S.”

This critical report urges awareness of the alcohol-cancer link and calls for societal action to reduce consumption.

item.title: ‘Avoid panic’: Amid HMPV scare, Pune district collector calls for taking precautionary measures - The Indian Express
item.description:
Pune District Collector Urges Caution Amid HMPV Cases

Publication Date: January 10, 2025 | Source: Indian Express

Pune District Collector Jitendra Dudi addressed concerns regarding the human metapneumovirus (HMPV), assuring the public that panic is unwarranted. Experts have indicated that this is a mild virus that requires basic precautionary measures.

  • Approximately 20 HMPV cases were reported in Pune, mainly among children, along with a few cases in adults with co-morbid conditions.
  • Global presence of HMPV has been confirmed, with no unusual surge in respiratory illness cases in India.
  • State health officials increased surveillance due to reports of an HMPV outbreak in China, but only five cases of Influenza A were diagnosed recently.
“This is not a new virus and we have urged people not to panic,” - Jitendra Dudi

Authorities emphasize the importance of consulting healthcare professionals if experiencing influenza-like symptoms. The state remains vigilant in monitoring potential outbreaks.

item.title: The hidden dangers of air pollution and fog on human health - The Times of India
item.description:
The Hidden Dangers of Air Pollution and Fog on Human Health

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Times of India

Air pollution and fog pose significant health risks to humans, particularly in urban areas where emissions are high. This article highlights the dangers of combined environmental factors on respiratory health.

  • Exposure to air pollution can lead to respiratory illnesses and cardiovascular diseases.
  • Fog exacerbates the effects of pollutants by trapping them close to the ground.
  • Certain demographics, including children and the elderly, are more vulnerable to air quality issues.
"The combination of air pollution and fog presents a unique challenge to public health that cannot be ignored."

Understanding and mitigating these risks is crucial for improving public health outcomes in affected regions.

item.title: Malaika Arora Feels 'Energised With The Winter Sun': 6 Health Benefits Of Sunbathing - TheHealthSite
item.description:
Malaika Arora Feels Energised With The Winter Sun: 6 Health Benefits Of Sunbathing

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Health Site

Malaika Arora emphasizes the importance of sunbathing even during winter, highlighting its numerous health benefits. She recently shared an Instagram post enjoying sunlight in her home, feeling energized.

Key Points:

  • Boosts vitamin D levels, essential for bone health and immune function.
  • Reduces symptoms of seasonal affective disorder (SAD).
  • Supports a healthy circadian rhythm, improving sleep quality and energy levels.
  • Enhances skin health by promoting collagen production.
  • Increases energy and alertness, combating fatigue.
  • Stimulates immune function, increasing white blood cell production.
"Energised with the winter sun." - Malaika Arora

Sunbathing during winter can provide significant health advantages, contributing to overall well-being and vitality.

item.title: Govt lab confirms HMPV infection in 8-yr-old; cases in Gujarat rise to 3 - Business Standard
item.description:
Govt lab confirms HMPV infection in 8-yr-old; cases in Gujarat rise to 3

Publication Date: Recent
Source: Business Standard

An eight-year-old boy from Gujarat's Sabarkantha district has been confirmed to have contracted human metapneumovirus (HMPV), raising the total number of cases in the state to three. He is currently being treated in a hospital but is stable.

  • The boy is from a family of farm laborers in Prantij taluka.
  • A private lab first detected HMPV, later confirmed by a government lab.
  • The boy is on a ventilator but his condition is stable.
  • A two-month-old boy from Rajasthan was the first reported case in Gujarat.
  • An 80-year-old man with HMPV is receiving treatment in Ahmedabad.
“He is currently under treatment and his condition is stable,” said Sabarkantha District Collector Ratankanvar Gadhavicharan.

HMPV spreads through respiratory droplets and contaminated surfaces, similar to the Respiratory Syncytial Virus.

item.title: HMPV in China: Government in contact with WHO on respiratory diseases, says foreign ministry - The Hindu
item.description:
China Maintains Communication with WHO on HMPV Cases

Date: January 10, 2025
Source: The Hindu

The Chinese foreign ministry confirmed ongoing communication with the WHO regarding respiratory diseases, particularly concerning the human metapneumovirus (HMPV) affecting China.

  • The Chinese foreign ministry stated that they prioritize the health of both citizens and foreigners.
  • HMPV has been circulating in humans for over 60 years.
  • China's CDC reported sustained high levels of HMPV cases in the latest update.
“The HMPV is not a new virus and has been circulating in humans for more than 60 years.” - Guo Jiakun, Foreign ministry spokesperson

The Chinese government's proactive communication may help alleviate public concerns about HMPV cases and emphasize the ongoing surveillance of respiratory diseases.

item.title: What to drink for weight loss? Nutritionist shares 5 detox beverages to reduce fat - Hindustan Times
item.description:
What to drink for weight loss? Nutritionist shares 5 detox beverages to reduce fat

Jan 10, 2025 02:20 PM IST - Hindustan Times

Hydration is crucial when trying to lose weight. The article emphasizes the importance of detox drinks, which provide natural goodness while being low in calories.

Key Points:

  • Importance of hydration in weight loss.
  • Detox water is low in calories and energizing.
  • 5 detox drinks recommended: Methi water, Fennel water, Cinnamon orange infusion, CFC tea (Coriander, fennel, and cumin), Tulsi and ginger root boost.
  • Benefits of detox water include detoxifying the body, adding electrolytes, vitamins, and minerals.
  • Experts highlight benefits such as improving metabolism and digestion.
“Detox water has a lot of benefits minus calories. These fruits add electrolytes, vitamins, and minerals [to water] and keep your body hydrated.” - Nutritionist Kavita Devgan

This article provides insights into how detox beverages can support weight loss and overall wellness.

item.title: Calling common virus ‘unknown’ essentially fear-mongering: FM responds to attention on increase in cases of HMPV in China - Global Times
item.description:
FM Responds to Misleading Claims About HMPV in China

Publication Date: January 6, 2025

Source: Global Times

The Chinese Foreign Ministry has addressed recent concerns over an increase in human metapneumovirus (HMPV) cases, highlighting that HMPV is not a new virus and calling media reports suggesting otherwise as fear-mongering.

  • Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Guo Jiakun stated HMPV has been circulating for at least 60 years.
  • Guo emphasized that respiratory infections are currently lower than last year in China.
  • The spokesperson noted that the WHO also confirmed HMPV is a common virus, not a new threat.
  • Proactive surveillance and communication efforts have been taken by China's health authorities.
  • Reports of overwhelmed hospitals due to HMPV are exaggerated according to both Guo and the WHO.
“Calling this common virus ‘unknown’ is inconsistent with basic science and essentially fear-mongering.” - Guo Jiakun

In conclusion, the Chinese government reassures that the health of all individuals within its borders remains a priority, and that transparency regarding respiratory diseases is being maintained.

item.title: Portraying common viruses as ‘unknown viruses’ alarmist: FM responds to concern regarding increase in HMPV infection in China - Global Times

item.title: HMPV Case LIVE: India saw over 200 infections till December; what WHO said about the virus? | Today News - Mint
item.description:
HMPV Cases in Gujarat Rise: Eight-Year-Old Boy Infected

Date: 10 Jan 2025 Source: Live Mint

As cases of Human Metapneumovirus (HMPV) rise in India, state governments are raising surveillance measures. A recent case of an eight-year-old boy in Gujarat adds to the growing number of infections.

  • HMPV infections now number three in Gujarat, increasing concern among health officials.
  • Health Minister JP Nadda reassured the public that HMPV is not new and urged for precautions during the winter illnesses surge.
  • Since January 7, nine cases have been reported in India with initial cases in Karnataka and Tamil Nadu.
  • The World Health Organization states HMPV is a common seasonal virus.
  • The virus primarily affects the respiratory system, with symptoms akin to common colds.
“Every child will have at least one infection with HMPV by their fifth birthday.” - Paul Hunter, Professor of Medicine

This incident emphasizes the ongoing importance of monitoring respiratory viruses and taking necessary precautions.

item.title: Union Health Ministry highlights state innovations to combat NCDs at national workshop - ETHealthWorld
item.description:
Union Health Ministry Highlights Innovations to Combat NCDs at National Workshop

Date: January 10, 2025 Source: ETHealthWorld

New Delhi: The Union Health Ministry, in collaboration with the Government of Telangana, hosted a two-day National Workshop on Non-Communicable Diseases (NCDs) on January 8–9, 2025, focusing on strategies to combat the growing burden of NCDs.

  • Emphasis on inter-sectoral collaboration and innovative practices.
  • Highlighting state-specific initiatives like Assam’s hypertension control program and Tamil Nadu’s NCD screenings.
  • Recognition of successful community-driven health initiatives, including Fit India campaign.
  • Strategies to enhance cancer care infrastructure discussed.
  • Importance of early detection in tackling NCDs emphasized, given that they account for over 66% of deaths in India.
Punya Salila Srivastava stated, “this national workshop marked a significant step toward achieving the government’s vision of a ‘Healthy India,’ emphasizing universal access to quality healthcare services and the reduction of premature mortality from NCDs.”

The workshop served as a crucial platform for sharing best practices and enhancing the collective response to the pressing health challenges of NCDs in India.
